newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.African stock market closing report.
newsitem.headline: S.African stock market closing report.

text.p: South African gold shares finished firmer on Monday but off highs reached in the morning as the volatile bullion price dipped a couple of dollars during the day.
Dealers said the market -- hit hard by the gold price's recent slide to 12-year lows -- was spooked by any downward movement in the metal price and small dips raised spectres of downward runs.
"Golds were firm at the start but they came back on the volatile bullion price," said James Scott at Societe Generale Frankel Pollak.
Gold fixed at $326.20 an ounce in the London afternoon session -- down from a morning fix of $328.05.
Dealers said the bullion price was expected to pull back further overnight and local gold stocks were likely to be bumped at the start on Tuesday.
"The guys are expecting the gold price to come back a bit more tonight," said another dealer who asked not to be identified.
Gold shares finished 16.3 points up at 1,008.3 points after touching a day's high of 1,022.5 points.
Industrial shares rose steadily all day to finish well up but just under a new year high of 8,981 points.
Dealers said good demand for blue chip stocks buoyed the index and underlying sentiment remained positive.
Wall Street's weakness last Friday and a softer opening on Monday appeared not to concern local stocks.
"There is still a good sentiment out there. We seem to be on our non-correlation with Wall Street," Scott said.
The industrial index ended 42 points stronger at 8,979.7.
Overall trade was pretty active in the afternoon after a quiet morning and 574 million rands worth of shares changed hands.
Dealers said futures-related trade was minimal with that market also fairly quiet.
Near-term industrial and all-share futures contracts finished more or less steady.
The industrial contract was last at 8,536/45 from 8,538 settlement and the all-share was at 6,712/20 from 6,735.
Gold futures took more of a bump from the bullion price's dip than the cash market, ending at 708/13 from 717.
The all-share index added seven points to finish at 7,431.9.

Mining house Gencor took a knock to finish 40 cents down at 19 rand on volume of 4.5 million shares but dealers said this had more to do with investors' tug-of-war between backing Gencor or the new London incorporated Billiton and not much to do with the drop in second quarter gold profit announced earlier.
Gencor announced distributable gold profit for the three months to end June of 60.65 million rand compared to 87.70 million rand in the preceding quarter.

Shares in South African hospital management company Netcare Ltd jumped in early trade to 214 cents from 200 cents after it announced at the weekend it had acquired a controlling interest in Clinic Holdings Limited (Clinics).
Netcare ended six cents up at 206 cents on volume of 2.9 million shares, while Clinics dropped 10 cents to end at 480 cents in meagre volumes of 4,000 shares.
Clothing company Towles, Edgar Jacobs Ltd (TEJ) shares jumped to finish at a new year high of 16 rand from 13.90 rand, ahead of an expected announcement on further acqusitions, dealers said.
-- Melanie Cheary, Johannesburg newsroom +27 11 482-1003
